RKV8(7) Pair with 7th order interpolant

This RKV8(7) pair's tableau is different from the RK (7,8) pair in Verner (1978). The coefficients of the 15th stage (a[14] in Python zero-based indexing)
and onwards are manually read out and typed from the scanned paper since the numbers cannot be copy-pasted. The coefficients work well within double-precision
computations in Python.

References
--------------------
Macdougall, Thomas. (1998). Global Error Estimators For Explicit Runge-Kutta Methods. Thesis. Queen's University, Kingston. Ontario, Canada. https://central.bac-lac.gc.ca/.item?id=MQ28227&op=pdf&app=Library&oclc_number=46583345
Verner, J. H. (1978). Explicit Runge-Kutta Methods with Estimates of the Local Truncation Error. SIAM Journal on Numerical Analysis, 15(4), 772â€“790. http://www.jstor.org/stable/2156853

c[0] = 0
c[1] = 2/27
c[2] = 1/9
c[3] = 1/6
c[4] = 5/12
c[5] = 1/2
c[6] = 5/6
c[7] = 1/6
c[8] = 2/3
c[9] = 1/4
c[10] = 1/3
c[11] = 1
c[12] = 1

a[1,0] = 2/27

a[2,:2] = [1/36, 1/12]

a[3,:3] = [1/24, 0, 1/8]

a[4,:4] = [5/12, 0, -25/16, 25/16]

a[5,:5] = [1/20, 0, 0, 1/4, 1/5]

a[6,:6] = [-25/108, 0, 0, 125/108, -65/27, 125/54]

a[7,:7] = [31/300, 0, 0, 0, 61/225, -2/9, 13/900]

a[8,:8] = [2, 0, 0, -53/6, 704/45, -107/9, 67/90, 3]

a[9,:9] = [-1269/2560, 0, 0, -647/1024, -73/16, 1859/512, -987/5120, 329/128, -35/512]

a[10,:10] = [-431/540, 0, 0, 23/108, -976/135, 299/54, -29/84, 5/2, 1/20, 128/315]

a[11,:11] = [2263/4100, 0, 0, -341/164, 4496/1025, -289/82, 15471/28700, 63/82, 153/820, -384/1435, 18/41]

a[12,:12] = [1741/2550, 0, 0, -1135/408, 6464/1275, -827/204, 13331/23800, 155/204, 23/102, 64/119, 0, 0]


# 8th order weights
b = [41/840, 0, 0, 0, 0, 34/105, 9/35, 9/35, 9/280, 0, 9/280, 41/840, 0]


# 7th order weights
bh = [26/525, 0, 0, 0, 0, 71/210, 1269/4900, 171/700, 9/350, 128/3675, 0, 0, 17/350]


# error estimator weights, e = bh - b
e = [1/1400, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1/70, 9/4900, -9/700, -9/1400, 128/3675, -9/280, -41/840, 17/350]

# 5 total extra stages for 7th order interpolant. The 1st extra stage is simply
# the 1st stage of the next step so it is essentially free.

c[13] = 1

a[13,:13] = [41/840, 0, 0, 0, 0, 34/105, 9/35, 9/35, 9/280, 0, 9/280, 41/840, 0]

c[14] = .3110177634953863863927417318829099695921243440655392728308332529142094

a[14,0] = .4352734390721701433165165378569484837135441233387398040206887174668185e-1

a[14,2] = 0
a[14,3] = 0
a[14,4] = 0
